entry.title: Every Saga Has a Beginning
entry.content:
Pivot, change, and ignite.

Update 2024-05-18

This is‚ÄîI believe‚Äîthe fourth incarnation of Zero to Hero.

Since I wrote this article a lot have changed, which I can summarize as
‚Äúlife got in the way even further.‚Äù

The text below is the original article that I wrote on May the Fourth, 2021.Since then, a lot have changed in my personal and professional life. So, keep in mind that the text below is a snapshot of the past, and things have evolved since then.

Currently, Zero to Hero serves as my personal blog where I write about what I think, when I think. You can find the latest articles on the home page.

In addition, I have removed the subscription-based content strategy, and I‚Äôm publishing everything on this platform for free.

Hello World, Hello Stars, Hello Universe

Hi there üëã,

As you can see, this is the new Zero to Hero.

Which begs the question ‚ÄúWhat is the ‚Äòold‚Äô ‚ÄòZero to Hero‚Äô then?‚Äù.

Just üêª with me, I‚Äôll get to it shortly. But, in a nutshell: Around 2018, I created a video course titled ‚ÄúJavaScript from Zero to Hero‚Äù. I gradually added more content, videos, lesson notes‚Ä¶ Yet, ‚Äúlife‚Äù got in the way and I was never able to finalize the course.

So, as of May the fourth 2021, I decided to make a radical change and start everything from scratch with a blank canvas and a different content strategy.

Coincidentally, May the Fourth 2021, is the International Star Wars Day, and also my 42nd birthday. There couldn‚Äôt have been any better day for this kind of a transformation üôÇ.

This very page is that blank canvas that you are looking at right now.

So, What‚Äôs Coming Up

Yes, his is ground zero. Yes, I‚Äôm starting everything from scratch.

This is a radical decision that deserves an explanation. In this article, I‚Äôll try to outline the whys and hows of this decision as best as I can.

The Content

I will create one (and only one) kinds of content here:

  • Free: Where anyone can read and learn from.

  • Why? Because, simply, and very plainly: I don‚Äôt need to make money from this.

I have a day job that pays well. Trying to make a living from this will only add unnecessary pressure and stress to my life. It will also limit my creativity and freedom. I will have to end up optimizing for impressions.

I DO NOT WANT THAT.

I want to create because I want to create. I don‚Äôt want to create to feed an algorithm.

I don‚Äôt want Zero to Hero to turn into a content mill. I don‚Äôt want it to be a burden. I want it to be a joy, so that I can create more valuable content, freely, without any constraints.

The Pivot

Every saga has a beginning.

So what‚Äôs the plan?

I‚Äôm recreating the existing content with a totally different approach:

I‚Äôll focus creating more textual content, diagrams and visualizations, source code, embedded code playgrounds, and the like.

I‚Äôll augment the textual content with videos only when it‚Äôs needed (like, for example, showing a complicated AWS Console setup, which is easier to see than to read and follow).

There are several reasons for that:

  • Creating video content is tenfold harder than creating a textual content: Publishing a five-minute video lesson takes at least ten-to-fifteen hours of time. Creating textual content is much faster.
  • Editing, updating, iterating textual content is much more convenient: It‚Äôs as simple as deleting some text, and adding the new text, updating images and other references. Per contra, for video, you‚Äôll have to reshoot your entire video, which will cost you at least another fifteen hours per video.
  • Textual content is searchable and indexable: With videos, you can achieve something similar with bookmarks, and annotations, but still it won‚Äôt be even close to the comfort you have with text.
  • You can copy/paste, save, backup, mix and mash text. With video, it‚Äôs a lot harder to do that.

Content is the King

‚ÄúSuccess isn‚Äôt always about greatness. It‚Äôs about consistency. Consistent hard work leads to success. Greatness will come.‚Äù ‚Äì Dwayne (the Rock) Johnson

It will take a while to think about the content strategy.

I have a plan‚Ä¶ several plans in fact. And I‚Äôll gradually get there.

My first action item is to maintain a writing cadence: I don‚Äôt know if this will be daily, every other day, weekly, or something different‚Ä¶ but I‚Äôll reserve an uninterrupted, focused, content creation time on my calendar.

Once I am comfortable with the cadence, then I‚Äôll think about the content strategy; not before.

A Change in the Process

I began working on ‚ÄúJavaScript: from Zero to Hero‚Äù around 2018. The course was a video course about creating and maintaining your JavaScript stack in a real-life production environment, paying special attention to things like scalability, fault-tolerance, high availability, disaster recovery, auditing, security‚Ä¶ As far as I could see, no one had come closer to creating a course like that. So there was a lot of value in creating it.

So why the sudden shift, you may‚Äîrightfully‚Äîask.

By the time of this writing, it is mid-2021. And I am‚Ä¶ more-or-less 70% complete, give or take a few percents.

If I continue with this pace, my guesstimate is, the course will not be released before late 2023. And I believe, this is turning out to be an uphill battle, and I need to change my parameters to expedite the process.

Right now, I find myself lucky if I can publish one video lesson per week. To be upfront and honest with you again, I don‚Äôt remember when was the last time I published a new video‚Ä¶ it has been at least several months.

I have (as of this writing, again) around fifty lectures to add before I finalize the course. So do the math yourself üôÇ.

‚Ä¶ Well, I did the math üôÇ If you consider the ever-changing pace of technology, that rate is unsustainable for an online technical video course. It is an uphill battle.

Is Creating a Video Course Really ‚Äúthat‚Äù Hard?

But why is that? I mean, isn‚Äôt that too much time for a just a ‚ÄúJavaScript‚Äù course?

Trust me, I thought about that too.

While thinking, I decided to put my thoughts into words.

There is a multitude of reasons, why the course took more than an average ‚Äúlet‚Äôs make an online recipe sharing web app with React and GraphQL‚Äù course:

  • Firstly, my responsibilities grew as I gained more clout within the company. This resulted in a more demanding job.
  • In addition, as the kids got older, my responsibilities as a parent, guardian, and a spouse grew‚ÄîNot everyone knows this, but we are a non-neurotypical family of four. And that multiplies the attention, care, and communication needs orders of magnitude compared with an equivalent ‚Äútypical‚Äù (if that‚Äôs a thing) household.
  • Plus, the course was not ‚Äújust‚Äù a JavaScript course: In the lessons, I talked about topics varying from virtual subnet setups to lambda functions to message queues‚Ä¶ It was deep and broad. And I didn‚Äôt want to sacrifice quality.

Ah, as a cherry on top of all of this ‚Äú‚ÄôRona‚Äù happened. We jumped into a seemingly endless year of lockdown, homeschooling, remote work, isolation. I call that ‚Äúsheltering at work‚Äù, and it‚Äôs much more than that indeed. The lockdown amplified the emotional roller-coasters that we, as a family, were having.

Resistance is Futile

I am an engineer. Always was, always will be.

Doing constraint optimizations is what I‚Äôm good at‚Äîone way of approaching the ‚Äúlack of time‚Äù challenge was to set a deadline, set milestones, and pressure myself to reach those milestones as best as you can.

Pushing myself further would have taken me to the limits of burning myself out. I simply did not have the luxury to burn out, so I decided to find a different solution.

A Quick Flashback

Let me add a few screenshots to show you how the course looked like.

The landing page.

The learning management system.

The application was truly slick, micro-services-based, learning management system. I‚Äôm planning to rework on it too, and share my progress here with y‚Äôall‚Äîalthough I‚Äôm sunsetting the current system, I‚Äôm proud of it. And I‚Äôm proud of everyone who has been with me through this journey.

Like I said, the goal of the course was to be something other than yet another ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs build a restaurant rating and comparison app using React and GraphQL‚Äù course. I wanted it to be something that teaches you how a real-life production application was built, evolved, and maintained.

I wanted to create a platform where the interested individuals will learn the following the hard way:

  • Develop robust, lean, and error-free apps.
  • Create reusable, modular, and modern codebases that stand the test of time.
  • Build, scale, diagnose, and monitor a full-stack production application.

It was an ambitious goal, I know. Still, I was step by step getting there.

Then Life Got in the Way

As I outlined before, while I‚Äôm working on Zero to Hero, a lot happened in the meantime. A lot have changed both in my personal and professional life. The project almost moved to a halt. And I‚Äôve realized a few things:

  • The scope of the course was way too big to be reasonably completed in time.
  • Creating a video-heavy content, while having a full-time job and two kids at school age required a lot of sacrifice from my personal time and my sanity.

I also realized all of this burden was creating a very heavy toll on my personal well-being and my relationship with my family.

Family is where I draw the line. Family comes first; always; no exceptions.

Erase and Rewind

Eventually‚Äîand took many months of debilitation‚ÄîI‚Äôve decided to put a ‚Äúhard reset‚Äù on everything:

  • I‚Äôve moved my Twitter to private.
  • I‚Äôve jumped off all other social media.
  • The only medium that I‚Äôve been sharing stuff for the last couple of months is LinkedIn.

And during that time frame, I‚Äôve been thinking about what to do‚Ä¶ how to restart, how to reignite.

And this web app that you see is the end result of months and months of thinking, introspection, and self-reflection.

Changing Perspective

After thinking about this a lot and weighing all my options: I‚Äôve decided to pivot my idea into a knowledge-sharing system that I can populate faster, easier, without friction‚Äîalmost naturally.

Sometimes you need a shift in your perspective. Sometimes you need a splash of water in your face. Almost always, you need both.

What will the new Zero to Hero be like?

Well, honestly, time will tell. I have a lot of ideas.

Videos are Holding You Back

That said, creating visual content for the last few years, I realized that not only creating video content is holding me back, but also videos are holding you back.

Think about it: The average video course is spoken at 150 words per minute, while you can read at-the-very-least 250 words per minute.

I know this is a blanket statement, and people with certain conditions have hard time reading things. And to certain people consuming video content at 2x speed is a much better to learn things than following text. But, in general, reading something takes much less time than watching an equivalent content.

In addition, you can read a lot faster if you have mastered scanning and skimming techniques. If you have read that thousand page brick-sized book before your final exam, you know what I mean üòÑ‚Äîtry that with watching video lessons.

With textual content, it‚Äôs much easier to find your own pace, adjust your speed, skip blocks of text, scan and skim the text to drill down further later‚Äîthat‚Äôs the beauty of text.

Moreover, you can search textual content easily. Even when you have properly-set-up bookmarks and annotations, and transcripts, searching inside a video is much harder.

And this one is for me: Creating textual content is way faster than creating audiovisual content. I can create more valuable content faster this way.

That said, I also do believe there needs to be a hybrid approach: The textual content needs to be augmented with clarifying videos to show how things work when they work the way they work.

Furthermore, inside a text-oriented web app, you can embed live coding playgrounds, other interactive tools.

You can create an app for the users of the system to take their own notes and annotate the content to their liking. Like you see a lot can be done, and text is the starting point. It‚Äôs the origin.

I‚Äôm also jotting down some of those ideas in my backlog, which will end up as useful widgets that add value to this new platform that you are reading and using right now.

Nothing is Lost: Everything Transforms

Tangentially: Everything in life is based on three main forces:

  • Rotation
  • Oscillation
  • And Transformation

Zero to Hero is no exception to that.

This post marks the beginning of a transformation phase.

The older content is not going anywhere. I have triple backups of everything. They will find their place here in some way, shape or form.

Onwards to a New Ride

This has been a wonderful ride so far. I cannot thank enough to everyone who have been with me. You mean a lot to me and words cannot express how grateful I am to have y‚Äôall by my side.

This is a new beginning.

Stay tuned: More will come.

May the source be with you ü¶Ñ,

Volkan.

entry.title: Volkan Uses
entry.content:
Tools and trinkets.

This is a list of tools, gadgets, software, and hardware I currently use, have liked, and find worth mentioning.

Disclaimer

I am not affiliated with any of the products or services mentioned here. I just share them because I like them.

Personal

  • Vadideki Geyik: Hands down, the best Turkish tech podcast.
  • zerotohero.dev: My blog (that you are reading right now).
  • My Twitter
  • My GitHub
  • My Twitch

Gadgets and Gizmos

  • LTT Screwdriver: A very high-quality ratcheting screwdriver.
  • Fisher Space Pen - The Original Astronaut Pen: The one that NASA spent ‚Äúmillions‚Äù to design.
  • KEPEAK Military Tactical Pen: You can write on paper and break thick glasses simultaneously.
  • Raspberry Pi: I use this to create small projects.
  • Tessel: Another IoT board that I used to use.
  • MagicFiber Microfiber Cleaning Cloths, 13 PACK: I have glasses; they need cleaning. MagicFiber is the best.
  • MagicFiber Extra Large Microfiber Cleaning Cloth: They said: ‚Äúbigger is better.‚Äù
  • Zeiss Lens Cleaning Spray: I use the best when my vision is at stake.
  • Elgato StreamDeck: One of the best investments I‚Äôve made. If you stream regularly, you must have this.
  • GAN Cube: It‚Äôs the best Rubik‚Äôs Cube out there.

Computer and Peripherals

  • Commodore 64: My first computer.
  • Mac Studio: I have a beefy Mac to do my work, content creation, gaming, and streaming.
  • Mac Mini Intel 2018: I use this as a local build and test environment, and experimental server.
  • Intel Nuc: I use this for other random experimentation. It has Ubuntu installed.
  • Logitech MX Master 3S: The fastest scroll ever; you‚Äôll never realize how important scrolling is before you use this mouse. It‚Äôs very ergonomic too.
  • Logitech MX Keys: I use this keyboard mostly. It is silent, with a small form factor, and like MX Master 3, it can connect to up to 3 devices at the same time, which is very useful.
  • Das Keyboard 4 Professional: My default keyboard choice. I use this keyboard when I need to type a lot. It has Chery MX Blue keys, making it very clicky and loud, but it‚Äôs very satisfying.
  • CalDigit Thunderbolt Station: Adds 18 more ports to your machine for extreme connectivity.
  • InnoView Portable Monitor, 15.6 Inch: I use this as a secondary monitor for streams as a dedicated 1080p source.
  • Apple iPad Pro 4th Gen (11 inch): I use it for many things, including monitoring the alternate destinations when I stream to multiple platforms.
  • Anker 2.4G Wireless Vertical Ergonomic Optical Mouse: It‚Äôs very ergonomic; it‚Äôs a fraction of the price of MX Master 3, and it‚Äôs amazingly precise and comfortable. If you need an no-fluff ergonomic mouse, this is the one.

Home Office / Office

  • MP Trio Max: This gives two additional monitors to my laptop. It‚Äôs a great tool when you need more screen real estate. And it‚Äôs very portable too, which makes it a great fit for office and travel.
  • Crank Adjustable Height Rolling Standing Desk: I use this as my desk. It‚Äôs very sturdy, and it‚Äôs easy to adjust the height.
  • CyberPower Intelligent LCD UPS System: I use this to protect my computer and other devices from power outages.
  • Power Strip Tower and Surge Protector: I use this to power my devices.
  • TBMax Cat 6 Ethernet Cable 50 ft - High-Speed Flat Cat6 Computer LAN Wire: I use this to connect my computer to the router. I don‚Äôt believe in Wi-Fi.
  • Keyspan by Tripp Lite PR-PRO3 Presentation Remote Pro Wireless w Laser: I have a cat.
  • Rain Design 10032 mStand Laptop Stand, Silver: I use this to raise my laptop to eye level. You‚Äôll never know when you need it.
  • Kogonee Wooden Digital Alarm Clock: You‚Äôll never know you need this before you use it.

Storage

  • Transcend 256GB Thunderbolt Solid State Drive StoreJet 500 for Mac: I use this when I need a temporary high-speed SSD drive.
  • WD 12TB Elements Desktop External Hard Drive: I use this to store raw production and post production assets; you cannot imagine how much space you need to create quality audiovisual content.

Disk Management

  • Daisy Disk: I use this to find out what‚Äôs taking up space on my disk.
  • Disk Drill: I use this to recover deleted files. I use Backblaze, but in rare cases, I might not have backed up the file, where Disk Drill comes to the rescue.

Window Management

  • Magnet: I use this to manage my windows.
  • Window Tidy: I use this along with Magnet.

Office Applications

  • Microsoft Office 365: I use this to create documents, spreadsheets, and presentations.
  • Google Workspace: I mainly use this to host emails for my various domains.
  • Grammarly: I use this to check my grammar and spelling. It‚Äôs a lifesaver!
  • Miro: I use this to create diagrams and mind maps.
  • World Clock Pro: I use this to keep track of time zones. It‚Äôs simple, super useful, and does one thing well. I love it!
  • Wondershare Edraw Max: I use this to create diagrams, mind maps, and technical drawings.
  • Omnigraffle: I use this as an alternative to Edraw Max.
  • Mozilla Thunderbird: I use this to manage my emails when I am fed up with Microsoft Outlook.

Browsers

I use several browsers; my main browser is Safari. It‚Äôs memory and battery-efficient, the default browser on macOS. People complain about its extension support, but I don‚Äôt use extensions much, so it‚Äôs not a problem.

Here‚Äôs a list of browsers that I use occasionally:

  • Safari
  • Vivaldi
  • Opera
  • Chrome
  • Firefox
  • Edge
  • Brave
  • Lynx
  • Gopher

Programming Languages

Here are some of the languages I use, have used, and liked, in no particular order:

  • JavaScript
  • Node.js
  • TypeScript
  • C
  • C++
  • Erlang
  • Haskell
  • Go
  • CSS
  • Sass
  • Java
  • Java Spring
  • DotNet
  • C#
  • Visual Basic
  • Basic
  • ASP
  • ASP.Net
  • YAML
  • XML
  • JSON
  • YANG
  • NETCONF
  • SQL
  • Handlebars
  • Python
  • Ruby
  • Rust

Code Editors and IDEs

  • Sublime Text: I use this when I need a lightweight code editor.
  • Vim: This is the editor that I use in the terminal. I use Vim emulation in any editor that supports it, too.
  • Visual Studio Code: I use this as an alternative code editor.
  • IntelliJ IDEA: I use this as my main IDE, along with other JetBrains IDEs.
  • WebStorm: The best IDE to do web-related development.
  • GoLand: The best IDE to do Go development.
  • PyCharm: The best IDE to do Python development.
  • RubyMine: The best IDE to do Ruby development.
  • CLion: The best IDE to do C/C++ development.
  • RustRover: The best IDE to do Rust development.
  • Zed: Honestly, I still prefer Sublime; it is a neat app, but Sublime is still the app that I launch by reflex when I want to quickly note something down.

Embedded Code Editors

  • CodeMirror: I use this when I need a code editor in my web apps.
  • Monaco: It‚Äôs another code editor that I use in my web apps.
  • Codepen: I use this when I need to share a code snippet with someone.
  • Repl.it: I use this when I need to share a code snippet along with a running environment with someone.
  • GitHub Gists: I use this when I need to share a code snippet with someone, but I don‚Äôt want to create a repository for it.
  • ObservableHQ: I use this when I need to share a code snippet with someone, but I want to add some explanation to it.

Terminal Emulators

  • Cool Retro Terminal: It‚Äôs just to have fun. I typically use iTerm for everything terminal-related.
  • iTerm2: I use this as my terminal emulator.
  • Hyper: A configurable, JavaScript-based terminal emulator.
  • Alacritty: A cross-platform, GPU-accelerated terminal emulator. Very minimalistic. It‚Äôs so minimalistic that you‚Äôll have to know tmux to be productive with it.

Tunneling

  • Ngrok: I use this to expose my local services to the Internet.

Desktop Virtualization

  • Parallels Desktop: I use this to run Windows and Linux virtual machines on my Mac. It‚Äôs the best desktop virtualization tool that you can run on a Mac.

Payment Gateways

  • Stripe: I use this to process payments. It‚Äôs developer-friendly, with great API documentation and support.
  • Paypal: I use this as an alternative to Stripe.
  • Gumroad: I use this to sell digital products.

Large Language Models

I have ‚Äúpro‚Äù subscriptions to all of these tools. I use them for all kinds of research and content creation.

  • ChatGPT: It generates text, images, and answers questions.
  • Perplexity: When you have Perplexity, you don‚Äôt need Google.
  • Claude: I use Claude in a similar way to ChatGPT.

Generative Art

  • Midjourney: I use this to create generative art.
  • Nero AI: I use this to upscale and modify my images.

Design Tools

  • xScope: I use this to measure things on my screen.
  • ImageOptim: I use this to optimize images for the web.
  • Paletton: I use this to find color palettes.
  • Sketch: I use this to create designs, I am stubbornly not using Figma as my main design tool.
  • Figma: This is an alternative design tool that I play with.
  • Adobe Acrobat Reader: I use this to read PDFs.
  • Adobe Fonts: I use this to find fonts and use them in my web apps.

Fonts and Themes

  • Mono Lisa: I use this as my main font.
  • PragmataPro Mono: I use this when I need to compare many things at once and I need a font with a huge x-height that works even at the smallest sizes. It is an acquired taste, and it requires some getting-used-to.
  • Operator Mono: Another decent (and overpriced) monotype font that I like.
  • Monokai Pro: I use this as my main theme.
  • Dracula Pro: I use this as an alternative theme.
  • Gruvbox: I use this when I need a change but don‚Äôt want to be so drastic. It works really well when I do written content such as editing a lot of markdown files.
  • Cyan Light: I don‚Äôt always work in a dark cave. Cyan Light is my preferred theme when there is a lot of ambient light that make a dark color scheme impractical.
  • Gray: This is my alternate light theme choice.

Music

  • YouTube Music: This is my main music app.
  • Spotify: I use this to listen to music, and podcasts too.
  • Avid Sibelius: The best music notation software in existence.
  • Arturia Piano V3: I use this to use different piano flavors when I practice.

Video Storage

  • YouTube: I use this to save screencasts that I‚Äôve created.
  • Vimeo: I use this to save and share videos too.
  • Twitch: Pro tip: If you highlight your entire stream, you can save it indefinitely on Twitch. Otherwise the stream recording is deleted after 60 days.

Video Processing

  • ScreenFlow: I use this to record my screen.
  • ffmpeg: A complete, cross-platform solution to record, convert, and stream audio and video.

Audio Processing

  • Adobe Audition: I use this to edit audio files.
  • Airfoil: I use this to stream audio from my Mac to other devices.
  • Audacity: I typically use this connected to my digital piano to record my music. It can also edit audio files.
  • Izotope RX 10: I use this to clean up my audio files. It is one of the best post-production tools out there.
  • Murf: I use this to create AI-generated Audio transcripts for the tutorials that I create. It‚Äôs a great time-saver.

Audio Gear

  • Harman Kardon SoundSticks Wireless Bluetooth Speaker System: I use this to listen to music. It‚Äôs a great speaker system, and it looks amazing too.
  • Mackie CR StealthBar Desktop PC Soundbar: Much reasonably-priced compared to competitors with great audio quality.
  • Sennheiser Consumer Audio Momentum 4 Wireless Headphones: I use this to listen to music when I am not at my desk, I also use it during live streams because Airpods have their own mind and pair with random devices when you least expect it, which is not good when you are streaming. In addition it‚Äôs perfect for Office and Home Office when you want to get into the zone.
  • Apple AirPods Pro: I use this during meetings and conferences. Because of its small form factor, it does not look as goofy as other over-the-ear headphones.

Streaming Gear

  • Audio-Technica ATH-M50xBL Professional Studio Monitor Headphones: Great audio quality, flat frequency response. Very comfy on the ears.
  • Shure SM7B: I use this to record my voice. It‚Äôs a great microphone, but it requires a lot of gain, so you need a good preamp to use it.
  • Cloudlifter CL-1 Mic Activator Preamp: I use this to boost the gain of my Shure SM7B microphone.
  • Elgato Game Capture HD 60 X: I use this to capture my stream sessions.
  • Elgato Camlink 4K: I use this to connect my camera to my Mac.
  • Panasonic HC v180 Camcorder: I use this as my camera when I stream.
  • Neewer 2 Packs Dimmable 5600K USB LED Video Light: Way cost-effective than the alternatives, such as Elgato. It does the same job. I use this to light up my face when I stream.
  • Instahibit Retractable 6x6.8ft Pull Down Green Screen: I use this to hide my messy room when I stream.
  • Focusrite Scarlett Solo 3rd Gen USB Audio Interface: I use this to connect my microphone to my Mac.
  • DTech HDMI Dummy Plug 4K Display Emulator: I use this to trick my Mac to think that I have a 4K monitor connected to it. It‚Äôs useful when you want to stream at 4K, but you don‚Äôt have a 4K monitor.
